components.data:
Diatom cultivation (liquid)

Grow the diatom culture to mid-log phase (≈ 8.0E6 cells/ml for Phaeodactylum tricornutum grown on F/2 media). We have investigated transformation efficiency throughout the growth curve and found this to be the sweetspot.

Diatom cultivation (liquid)

Grow the diatom culture to mid-log phase (≈ 8.0E6 cells/ml for Phaeodactylum tricornutum grown on F/2 media). We have investigated transformation efficiency throughout the growth curve and found this to be the sweetspot.

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 1 of Diatom Transformation via Bacterial Conjugation
source_data.annotation:
-  The original protocol plated the culture (250uL of 1.0E8 cells/ml) on 1/2 strength L1, 1% agar plates for 4 days prior to transformation.

 

-  We have been investigating liquid cultivation because many diatom species do not survive on agar.

source_data.annotation:
Cultivation Conditions

 

-  Cultivation in 0.2 um-filtered L1 media prepared using seawater collected from the Gulf of Mexico.

-  80 - 100 μmol photons m-2 s-1 provided by Philips Daylightt Delux 40 watt T12 flourscent tubes.

-  Semi-continuous operation in 1L bulbble column bioreactors (500 - 800 ml working volume).

-  0.2 μm filtered air containing 1% CO2 provides aeration/agitation at 0.2 vvm.

components.data:
Prepare E. coli starter culture

Grow 1 mL of E. coli culture overnight (16-20 hrs) in LB+antibiotic for each planned transformation. We grow them at 37°C at 270 rpm in a shaking incubator.
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
Prepare E. coli starter culture

Grow 1 mL of E. coli culture overnight (16-20 hrs) in LB+antibiotic for each planned transformation. We grow them at 37°C at 270 rpm in a shaking incubator.

components.data:
Outgrow E. coli

Dilute cells 1:50 into 50 mL of fresh LB+antibiotic for each planned transformation.

On the day of transformation, use the overnight culture to inoculate 50 mL of fresh LB+antibiotic for each planned transformation.

  • Grow to an OD600 of 0.8 - 1.0 (37°C with 270 rpm shaking).
  • This takes about 3-4 hours.

components.data:
Concentrate the diatom and E. coli cultures

Centrifuge both cultures at 3000 x g for 10 minutes.

  • The diatom and E. coli cultures should be centrifuged at around the same time to minimize the amount of time they spend concentrated.

 

E. coli:

  • Centrifuge 50 mL of culture for each transformation and resuspend in 500 uL of SOC medium.
  •  

Phaeodactylum tricornutum:

  • Measure cell concentration with FlowCam or haemocytometer.
  • Centrifuge 2.5E8 cells and resuspend in 500 uL of L1 medium.

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 4 of Diatom Transformation via Bacterial Conjugation (AKA. full contact microbiology)
source_data.annotation: The original protocol scraped the agar plates the culture was initiated on using 500uL F/2, then adjusted the volume to attain 5.0 E8 cells/ml. We have found no difference so far in transformation effficiency between liquid- and plate-initiated cultures.

components.data:
Conjugation

  • Mix 200 μl of E. coli cells with 200 μl of Phaeodactylum tricornutum cells.
  • Spread the mixture on transformation plates (0.5x BG-11 with 5% LB and 1% agar).
  • Incubate plates for 90 minutes at 30°C in the dark.
  • Move plates to light incubator (18°C and 80 μmol photons m-2 s-1) for 2 days.

Negative controls

  • Mix 200 μl of SOC medium with 200 μl of Phaeodactylum tricornutum cells.
  • Mix 200 μl of L1 medium with 200 μl of E. coli cells.
  • Incubate and treat plates identically to conjugation plates.

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 5 of Diatom Transformation via Bacterial Conjugation (AKA. full contact microbiology)
source_data.annotation:
-  The authors of the original protocol suggested spreading the mixture near, but not touching, the edges of the plate, as this mixture will be scraped and replated in 2 days.

 

-  According to Diner et. al, the conjugation occurs during the 2-day incubation.

 

-  We have found greater success in using 0.5x BG-11 medium made with seawater instead of 0.5x L1 medium.

comments.name: Philip Weyman
comments.comment_text: The two day period after conjugation and before selection is important for expression of the newly introduced antibiotic resistance gene. Going straight to selection after the 30C incubation results in fewer colonies, probably because there is not enough time to get the resistance gene expressed properly.

components.data:
Selection

  • Collect cells by adding 1 mL of L1 medium. Use a cell scraper to concentrate cells and medium to one side of the plate. Transfer resuspended cells to a 1.5 ml microcentrifuge tube with a P1000 pipette and filter tips.
  • Plate 200 μl of the cell suspension on selection plates.
  • Incubate at 18°C and 80 μmol photons m-2 s-1 until colonies appear.

components.data:
Colony identification

After a minimum of 8-12 days, untransformed Phaeodactylum tricornutum cells die off, and colonies of transformed cells begin to appear – in some cases, this can take 3-4 weeks.
